articles.headline: Calls for Governor to Quit in Scandal
articles.snippet: Leaders called for Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois to step aside, as elements of the case came into focus.
articles.abstract: Leaders called for Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois to step aside, as elements of the case came into focus.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois returned to work here on Wednesday amid whirlwind efforts across the state and country to remove him from office before he could make an appointment to the vacant United States Senate seat that is the root of a debilitating criminal case against him.

articles.headline: House Passes Auto Rescue Plan
articles.snippet: The fate of the measure remained uncertain because of shaky support among Senate Republicans.
articles.abstract: The fate of the measure remained uncertain because of shaky support among Senate Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The House voted on Wednesday to approve a $14 billion government rescue of the American automobile industry, but the bailout plan, which would provide emergency loans to General Motors and Chrysler, was in jeopardy because of strong Republican opposition in the Senate.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Best Bets in Cameras, Under $300
articles.snippet: Once again, a search for the best digital cameras that cost less than $300. And the winners are . . .
articles.abstract: Once again, a search for the best digital cameras that cost less than $300. And the winners are . . .
articles.lead_paragraph: Dear camera companies of the world:

articles.headline: Pressing Its Investors, GMAC Says It Lacks the Capital to Be a Bank
articles.snippet: The firm that controls GMAC used the threat of bankruptcy to try to compel bondholders to accept plans for a bond-exchange program that many investors had been resisting.
articles.abstract: The firm that controls GMAC used the threat of bankruptcy to try to compel bondholders to accept plans for a bond-exchange program that many investors had been resisting.
articles.lead_paragraph: As lawmakers debated a bailout package for Detroit’s big automobile companies, the future of an important piece of the industry was being negotiated on a parallel track in New York on Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Leslie Wayne

articles.headline: Obama Team Set on Environment
articles.snippet: Barack Obama picked a Nobel Prize-winning physicist, Steven Chu, as his energy secretary.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama picked a Nobel Prize-winning physicist, Steven Chu, as his energy secretary.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President-elect Barack Obama has selected his top energy and environmental advisers, including a Nobel Prize-winning physicist and the former head of the Environmental Protection Agency, presidential transition officials said Wednesday.

articles.headline: U.S. Joins Effort to Bar Claims on Iraqi Coffers
articles.snippet: The U.S. has joined an effort to block claims against Iraq stemming from Saddam Hussein’s rule.
articles.abstract: The U.S. has joined an effort to block claims against Iraq stemming from Saddam Hussein’s rule.
articles.lead_paragraph: George Charchalis says he has never really recovered from the ordeal he endured after Saddam Hussein’s Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and James Glanz

articles.headline: Money and Lobbyists Hurt European Efforts to Curb Gases
articles.snippet: Setting up a workable market for climate change credits in Europe has proved difficult and contentious, pointing to pitfalls for the U.S. as it begins to consider a similar system.
articles.abstract: Setting up a workable market for climate change credits in Europe has proved difficult and contentious, pointing to pitfalls for the U.S. as it begins to consider a similar system.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS  The European Union started with a high-minded ecological goal: encouraging companies to cut their greenhouse gases by making them pay for each ton of carbon dioxide they emitted into the atmosphere.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Fighting Foreclosures, F.D.I.C. Chief Draws Fire
articles.snippet: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation chief called for billions in aid for homeowners, angering officials.
articles.abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation chief called for billions in aid for homeowners, angering officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the weekend before Thanksgiving, Washington’s top financial regulators were gathered on a conference call to discuss the rescue of the banking giant Citigroup when Sheila C. Bair, the chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, interrupted with a concern.

articles.headline: YouTube Videos Pull In Real Money
articles.snippet: Making videos for YouTube -- a pastime for millions of Web surfers -- is now a way to make a living.
articles.abstract: Making videos for YouTube -- a pastime for millions of Web surfers -- is now a way to make a living.
articles.lead_paragraph: Making videos for YouTube  for three years a pastime for millions of Web surfers  is now a way to make a living.

articles.headline: A Massacre in Congo, Despite Nearby Support
articles.snippet: The spasm of violence shows the cruelty of the armed groups and the problems plaguing U.N. peacekeepers.
articles.abstract: The spasm of violence shows the cruelty of the armed groups and the problems plaguing U.N. peacekeepers.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIWANJA, Congo  At last the bullets had stopped, and François Kambere Siviri made a dash for the door. After hiding all night from firefights between rebels and a government-allied militia over this small but strategic town, he was desperate to get to the latrine a few feet away.

articles.headline: Iraq Bomb Kills 48 in Volatile North
articles.snippet: The attack in northern Iraq during a meeting of local leaders was one of the worst in recent months.
articles.abstract: The attack in northern Iraq during a meeting of local leaders was one of the worst in recent months.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber attacked a packed restaurant on Thursday where Sunni Arabs and Kurds were meeting to ease friction in the tense northern city of Kirkuk. At least 48 people were killed in the bombing, apparently aimed at provoking extremists along widening ethnic fault lines just as American plans to withdraw militarily from Iraq became official.
